17  But in the following instructions I do not commend you, because when you come together it is not for the better but for the worse.  18  For, in the first place, when you come together as a church, I hear that there are divisions among you. And I believe it in part,  19  for there must be factions among you in order that those who are genuine among you may be recognized.  20  When you come together, it is not the Lord's supper that you eat.  21  For in eating, each one goes ahead with his own meal. One goes hungry, another gets drunk.  22  What! Do you not have houses to eat and drink in? Or do you despise the church of God and humiliate those who have nothing? What shall I say to you? Shall I commend you in this? No, I will not.
23  For I received from the Lord what I also delivered to you, that the Lord Jesus on the night when he was betrayed took bread,  24  and when he had given thanks, he broke it, and said, “This is my body, which is for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”  25  In the same way also he took the cup, after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood. Do this, as often as you drink it, in remembrance of me.”  26  For as often as you eat this bread and drink the cup, you proclaim the Lord's death until he comes.
27  Whoever, therefore, eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be guilty concerning the body and blood of the Lord.  28  Let a person examine himself, then, and so eat of the bread and drink of the cup.  29  For anyone who eats and drinks without discerning the body eats and drinks judgment on himself.  30  That is why many of you are weak and ill, and some have died.  31  But if we judged ourselves truly, we would not be judged.  32  But when we are judged by the Lord, we are disciplined so that we may not be condemned along with the world.
33  So then, my brothers, when you come together to eat, wait for one another—  34  if anyone is hungry, let him eat at home—so that when you come together it will not be for judgment. About the other things I will give directions when I come.
Icebreaker: When should the first snow happen?
Read the passage
Any questions about the passage?
What factions or divisions is Paul referring to? What behavior is the problem?
Rich and poor Christians in the church. There are people (most likely rich) who are indulging themselves and eating all of the food/drink before others are able to join.
What attitude does Paul want them to have during gatherings?
Instead of selfishly indulging, Paul wants them to have greater regard for one another. Paul wants them to actually practice unity when they meet together. Don’t forget one another over the food or otherwise.
What is communion? How are the Corinthians incorrectly treating communion?
Communion is a practice instituted by Jesus for Christians to remember his death and resurrection. It serves as a representation of his sacrificed body and shed blood. The way that the Corinthians are behaving is making them fail to take the Lord’s supper (v20). They’re not examining themselves in a manner that corresponds to proper posture for communion.
What does Paul want people to do before taking communion? What does this mean in the context of this passage?
He wants them to examine themselves. Typically we take this as looking at our own lives and our own sinfulness. But Paul challenges the Corinthians to think about how they’re treating the body of believers. Not simply an inward, ‘me and God’ practice, but one that looks at how we’re interacting with other believers.
How can we practice regarding one another more in our fellowship? Or being more mindful/aware of one another?
We want people to feel included and seen, particularly when we’re together.
Some may not have the finances to eat out all the time or at certain places.
Fellowship events shouldn’t ALWAYS be catered to a certain type of person.
How do we fellowship without having to be BFFs with everyone?

1 Cor 12:12-31
12 For just as the body is one and has many members, and all the members of the body, though many, are one body, so it is with Christ. 13 For in one Spirit we were all baptized into one body—Jews or Greeks, slaves or free—and all were made to drink of one Spirit.
14 For the body does not consist of one member but of many. 15 If the foot should say, “Because I am not a hand, I do not belong to the body,” that would not make it any less a part of the body. 16 And if the ear should say, “Because I am not an eye, I do not belong to the body,” that would not make it any less a part of the body. 17 If the whole body were an eye, where would be the sense of hearing? If the whole body were an ear, where would be the sense of smell? 18 But as it is, God arranged the members in the body, each one of them, as he chose. 19 If all were a single member, where would the body be? 20 As it is, there are many parts, yet one body.
21 The eye cannot say to the hand, “I have no need of you,” nor again the head to the feet, “I have no need of you.” 22 On the contrary, the parts of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable, 23 and on those parts of the body that we think less honorable we bestow the greater honor, and our unpresentable parts are treated with greater modesty, 24 which our more presentable parts do not require. But God has so composed the body, giving greater honor to the part that lacked it, 25 that there may be no division in the body, but that the members may have the same care for one another. 26 If one member suffers, all suffer together; if one member is honored, all rejoice together.
27 Now you are the body of Christ and individually members of it. 28 And God has appointed in the church first apostles, second prophets, third teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healing, helping, administrating, and various kinds of tongues. 29 Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all work miracles? 30 Do all possess gifts of healing? Do all speak with tongues? Do all interpret? 31 But earnestly desire the higher gifts.
And I will show you a still more excellent way.
Icebreaker: If you were a kitchen utensil, what would you be?
Read the passage
Any questions about the passage?
What’s the deal with spiritual gifts at Corinth?
Corinthians are gifted but still not spiritually mature
They see some gifts being more superior than others
They’re confused about the source of their gifts (pagan or otherwise)
Gifts are being used inappropriately which is causing division
How does Paul want us to treat the “lesser” or “weaker” gifts? Why?
Verse 24-25 - he wants us to give greater honor
So that there is unity and care for one another
This exhortation fits into the larger message of this letter and fits with the issues that Corinth is dealing with. The gifts are meant for the body, even the ones that are ‘lesser’.
What’s required for v26 to happen in real life? How can we foster this in YAF?
It requires people to know one another and be in each others’ lives. We cannot know what happens (suffering or otherwise) in another brother/sister unless there is a relationship. As trust builds, we also need to exercise courage to share and allow people to see what’s going on in our lives.
Compare list of gifts in v28 versus v8-10. What is Paul trying to communicate with this new list?
The second list includes gifts that are less supernatural, arguably more ‘boring.’ Paul wants to expand the view of gifting. The Corinthians might highly value the supernatural ones leading to marginalization of the ‘boring’ gifts. Again, striving for unity in the church.
How do we know our gift?
Some possible answers (no need to have exhaustive answer for this last question):
Through other people pointing them and affirming
Through finding ourselves in situations to exercise certain gifts
Through unique willingness or ease to serve in areas compared to other people

1 Cor 12:1-11
Now concerning spiritual gifts, brothers, I do not want you to be uninformed.  2  You know that when you were pagans you were led astray to mute idols, however you were led.  3  Therefore I want you to understand that no one speaking in the Spirit of God ever says “Jesus is accursed!” and no one can say “Jesus is Lord” except in the Holy Spirit.
4  Now there are varieties of gifts, but the same Spirit;  5  and there are varieties of service, but the same Lord;  6  and there are varieties of activities, but it is the same God who empowers them all in everyone.  7  To each is given the manifestation of the Spirit for the common good.  8  For to one is given through the Spirit the utterance of wisdom, and to another the utterance of knowledge according to the same Spirit,  9  to another faith by the same Spirit, to another gifts of healing by the one Spirit,  10  to another the working of miracles, to another prophecy, to another the ability to distinguish between spirits, to another various kinds of tongues, to another the interpretation of tongues.  11  All these are empowered by one and the same Spirit, who apportions to each one individually as he wills.
Icebreaker: What is your favorite holiday tradition?
Read the passage
Any questions about the passage?
Feel free to reserve questions about specific gifts for the large group
What issue is Paul addressing in this passage?
Corinthians have some misunderstanding about spiritual gifts. They’re getting confused about the outward appearance of spiritual gifts whether it’s something from God or something from pagan beliefs. These manifestations are from God so long as they affirm Christ.
*Worth to make sure everyone knows what spiritual gifts are.
What are three things that Paul says about spiritual gifts in v4-6?
4 - different types given by the Spirit
5 - intended to be used in service (like Lord Jesus)
6 - result of God’s working in a person
What are some healthy and unhealthy approaches or views of spiritual gifts?
We don’t want to ignore or deny these good, spiritual gifts from God. These are things we should seek and practice for the benefit of the church. At the same time, we cannot overvalue the gifts making them ultimate goals. Paul tells us that they are uniquely given by God, meaning we cannot ‘force’ God to give us certain gifts. They aren’t things that we ‘deserve.’ We should also be using them for purposes outside of what God intends.
Have you encountered or experienced any of these listed gifts before?
Opportunity for people to share and testify. No need to parse out the theology behind the events.

1 Cor 13
If I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but have not love, I am a noisy gong or a clanging cymbal.  2  And if I have prophetic powers, and understand all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have all faith, so as to remove mountains, but have not love, I am nothing.  3  If I give away all I have, and if I deliver up my body to be burned, but have not love, I gain nothing.
4  Love is patient and kind; love does not envy or boast; it is not arrogant  5  or rude. It does not insist on its own way; it is not irritable or resentful;  6  it does not rejoice at wrongdoing, but rejoices with the truth.  7  Love bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
8  Love never ends. As for prophecies, they will pass away; as for tongues, they will cease; as for knowledge, it will pass away.  9  For we know in part and we prophesy in part,  10  but when the perfect comes, the partial will pass away.  11  When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I gave up childish ways.  12  For now we see in a mirror dimly, but then face to face. Now I know in part; then I shall know fully, even as I have been fully known.
13  So now faith, hope, and love abide, these three; but the greatest of these is love.

Read the passage
Any questions about the passage?
Why does Paul include chapter 13 in the context of the letter?
It is important - it is eternal
Love needed for unity in how we interact
Love is needed for exercising gifts properly
Faith (+knowledge) in itself is insufficient without love
Describe the love Paul is referring to? How does this contrast our cultural understanding of love?
Love is concrete and robust and not fragile
Broader than romantic
Love is something that exists underneath our actions
But at the same time, an action can come without love
Love is not simply a feeling, nor simply an action (ie social action)
Culture may not think love is righteous or has integrity (contrasting in v6 ‘wrongdoing’)
Compare to work or corporate life
Why will ‘love never end’ (v8)?
love=God, God = doesn’t end, love = doesn’t end
In eternity, faith and hope will be fully realized. Love will still exist because the relationship/communion with God will be there.
What is Paul talking about in v9-12?
Love is greater than any spiritual gift. The spiritual gifts are things that point to and help us learn about who God is. These will be unnecessary when we are in eternity. All of those things are a shadow of what we will understand in the future. It’s all the more reason why love is the emphasis.
Which of the characteristics of love are the most difficult for you?
Please share personal examples!

1 Cor 14
Pursue love, and earnestly desire the spiritual gifts, especially that you may prophesy.  2  For one who speaks in a tongue speaks not to men but to God; for no one understands him, but he utters mysteries in the Spirit.  3  On the other hand, the one who prophesies speaks to people for their upbuilding and encouragement and consolation.  4  The one who speaks in a tongue builds up himself, but the one who prophesies builds up the church.  5  Now I want you all to speak in tongues, but even more to prophesy. The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks in tongues, unless someone interprets, so that the church may be built up.
6  Now, brothers, if I come to you speaking in tongues, how will I benefit you unless I bring you some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching?  7  If even lifeless instruments, such as the flute or the harp, do not give distinct notes, how will anyone know what is played?  8  And if the bugle gives an indistinct sound, who will get ready for battle?  9  So with yourselves, if with your tongue you utter speech that is not intelligible, how will anyone know what is said? For you will be speaking into the air.  10  There are doubtless many different languages in the world, and none is without meaning,  11  but if I do not know the meaning of the language, I will be a foreigner to the speaker and the speaker a foreigner to me.  12  So with yourselves, since you are eager for manifestations of the Spirit, strive to excel in building up the church.
13  Therefore, one who speaks in a tongue should pray that he may interpret.  14  For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays but my mind is unfruitful.  15  What am I to do? I will pray with my spirit, but I will pray with my mind also; I will sing praise with my spirit, but I will sing with my mind also.  16  Otherwise, if you give thanks with your spirit, how can anyone in the position of an outsider say “Amen” to your thanksgiving when he does not know what you are saying?  17  For you may be giving thanks well enough, but the other person is not being built up.  18  I thank God that I speak in tongues more than all of you.  19  Nevertheless, in church I would rather speak five words with my mind in order to instruct others, than ten thousand words in a tongue.
20  Brothers, do not be children in your thinking. Be infants in evil, but in your thinking be mature.  21  In the Law it is written, “By people of strange tongues and by the lips of foreigners will I speak to this people, and even then they will not listen to me, says the Lord.”  22  Thus tongues are a sign not for believers but for unbelievers, while prophecy is a sign not for unbelievers but for believers.  23  If, therefore, the whole church comes together and all speak in tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are out of your minds?  24  But if all prophesy, and an unbeliever or outsider enters, he is convicted by all, he is called to account by all,  25  the secrets of his heart are disclosed, and so, falling on his face, he will worship God and declare that God is really among you.
V1-6 = reasons prophecy is better
V7-12 = problem of tongues
V13-19 = solution for problem
V20-25 = again prefer prophecy

Read the passage
Any questions about the passage?
What’s the issue that Paul is addressing? How do tongues and prophecy compare to one another?
Corinthians were misusing tongues alongside exalting and overvaluing these gifts. Both tongues and prophecy can communicate something from God. Tongues require an interpreter since it’s most likely in a different language while prophecy does not.
How can tongues/prophecy affect other Christians in the church? How can they affect non-Christians in the church?
Can be weird/uncomfortable for everyone, especially if unfamiliar
Can cause division if people differ in views of these gifts
Allows interpreters to know they have the gift if they hear tongues
Process between tongues and interpretation can be a supernatural witness to non-Christians
Ideally can be edifying to the body
What is Paul’s primary concern regarding tongues and prophecy? Why?
Paul is concerned about the Corinthians edifying one another with these gifts. He wants the gifts to be used properly and not abused for selfish gain. It all fits into his overarching theme of unity! Even the gifts play a role in the church to build up and move towards unity.
If we don’t regularly practice tongues or prophecy, what do we do with this passage?
Allow the group to toss this around for a while. They might not have answers but this is just to brainstorm an application together.
In what ways can we take part in edifying the body of believers?
Not limited to what we’re gifted in. Challenge the group in how they can serve the fellowship and the church. Perhaps consider why we don’t want to take part in edifying or the struggles that come with it.

1 Cor 15

42  So is it with the resurrection of the dead. What is sown is perishable; what is raised is imperishable.  43  It is sown in dishonor; it is raised in glory. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body.  45  Thus it is written, “The first man Adam became a living being”; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit.  46  But it is not the spiritual that is first but the natural, and then the spiritual.  47  The first man was from the earth, a man of dust; the second man is from heaven.  48  As was the man of dust, so also are those who are of the dust, and as is the man of heaven, so also are those who are of heaven.  49  Just as we have borne the image of the man of dust, we shall also bear the image of the man of heaven.

Icebreaker: What is the last thing you did for the first time?
Read v35-44. What can we gather from these verses when comparing earthly to resurrected bodies? What do we learn about God in these verses?
The two bodies are very different. They’ll have different appearances but have the same entity like a seed turning into a plant. They’re completely distinct as if they were different species. They’ll be different in brilliance and nature like heavenly bodies of space. These new bodies will not die or perish. All of these bodies are created by God. He is powerful and creative to make these varieties of bodies, including our future, resurrected bodies.
Read v45-49. How are our bodies like Adam? How will our bodies be like Jesus?
Like Adam, we are like dust and will return to dust. Like Adam, we are finite and fallen. Like Jesus, we will have bodies that are perfect like how Jesus lived. Like Jesus, we will have new, physical bodies like Jesus’ resurrected one.
Read v50-58. How and when will this transformation happen? Why do we need these resurrected bodies?
V52 - it will happen instantaneously when Jesus returns at the trumpet. It will happen to all Christian whether they are dead/sleeping or alive.
We need these bodies to be with God. Our earthly bodies, tainted with sin and death, cannot inherit the kingdom of God or be with the imperishable or immortal. God’s holiness and glory would overwhelm our earthly bodies.
How is this promise of resurrected bodies relevant for us today?
ẞß gives us hope in this life so that death does not have final powerjo or victory over us (v55)
It serves as a basis and hopeful reason for laboring for the Lord (v58)

Now I would remind you, brothers, of the gospel I preached to you, which you received, in which you stand,  2  and by which you are being saved, if you hold fast to the word I preached to you—unless you believed in vain.
3  For I delivered to you as of first importance what I also received: that Christ died for our sins in accordance with the Scriptures,  4  that he was buried, that he was raised on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures,  5  and that he appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve.  6  Then he appeared to more than five hundred brothers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have fallen asleep.  7  Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles.  8  Last of all, as to one untimely born, he appeared also to me.  9  For I am the least of the apostles, unworthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.  10  But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace toward me was not in vain. On the contrary, I worked harder than any of them, though it was not I, but the grace of God that is with me.  11  Whether then it was I or they, so we preach and so you believed.
12  Now if Christ is proclaimed as raised from the dead, how can some of you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?  13  But if there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised.  14  And if Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain and your faith is in vain.  15  We are even found to be misrepresenting God, because we testified about God that he raised Christ, whom he did not raise if it is true that the dead are not raised.  16  For if the dead are not raised, not even Christ has been raised.  17  And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile and you are still in your sins.  18  Then those also who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished.  19  If in Christ we have hope in this life only, we are of all people most to be pitied.
20  But in fact Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.  21  For as by a man came death, by a man has come also the resurrection of the dead.  22  For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ shall all be made alive.  23  But each in his own order: Christ the firstfruits, then at his coming those who belong to Christ.  24  Then comes the end, when he delivers the kingdom to God the Father after destroying every rule and every authority and power.  25  For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.  26  The last enemy to be destroyed is death.  27  For “God has put all things in subjection under his feet.” But when it says, “all things are put in subjection,” it is plain that he is excepted who put all things in subjection under him.  28  When all things are subjected to him, then the Son himself will also be subjected to him who put all things in subjection under him, that God may be all in all.
29  Otherwise, what do people mean by being baptized on behalf of the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are people baptized on their behalf?  30  Why are we in danger every hour?  31  I protest, brothers, by my pride in you, which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die every day!  32  What do I gain if, humanly speaking, I fought with beasts at Ephesus? If the dead are not raised, “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.”  33  Do not be deceived: “Bad company ruins good morals.”  34  Wake up from your drunken stupor, as is right, and do not go on sinning. Read v1-11.  Review Paul’s encounter with Jesus. How was it different from other apostles? Why would he describe himself as “untimely born” (v8)?
Paul was named Saul before and was a persecutor of Christians. On a road to Damascus, a bright light shone on Saul. The people with him fell on the ground and Jesus spoke to Saul asking why Saul was persecuting him (Jesus). From there, Saul was renamed and received a commission from Jesus, changing the trajectory of Paul’s life completely. Unlike the other apostles, Paul never met Jesus while Jesus was alive. His encounter with Jesus happened after Jesus resurrected and ascended, so the latest encounter among the apostles. “Untimely born” or “abnormally born” is also a term for ‘stillbirth.’ Paul says that his relationship with Jesus is ‘premature’ because he never walked with Jesus when he was alive. The other apostles knew Jesus for much longer and resurrected Jesus was an extension. For Paul, his relationship was only through the post-resurrected Christ.
Look at v12-19. What issue is Paul addressing? What are some consequences if there’s no bodily resurrection?

He puts Adam and Jesus against one another. Adam is the ‘origin’ of the first death while Christ is the ‘origin’ of new life. Jesus’ resurrection undos the effect of Adam on mankind. They both cover all of humanity and representatives (or firstfruits) of all humanity.
Look at v29-34. How does resurrection relate to “eat and drink, for tomorrow we die” (v32)?
If there’s no resurrection of the dead, then you only live once. All we need to do is maximize and enjoy the current life with nothing in the future.

1 Cor 16
Now concerning the collection for the saints: as I directed the churches of Galatia, so you also are to do.  2  On the first day of every week, each of you is to put something aside and store it up, as he may prosper, so that there will be no collecting when I come.  3  And when I arrive, I will send those whom you accredit by letter to carry your gift to Jerusalem.  4  If it seems advisable that I should go also, they will accompany me.
5  I will visit you after passing through Macedonia, for I intend to pass through Macedonia,  6  and perhaps I will stay with you or even spend the winter, so that you may help me on my journey, wherever I go.  7  For I do not want to see you now just in passing. I hope to spend some time with you, if the Lord permits.  8  But I will stay in Ephesus until Pentecost,  9  for a wide door for effective work has opened to me, and there are many adversaries.
10  When Timothy comes, see that you put him at ease among you, for he is doing the work of the Lord, as I am.  11  So let no one despise him. Help him on his way in peace, that he may return to me, for I am expecting him with the brothers.
12  Now concerning our brother Apollos, I strongly urged him to visit you with the other brothers, but it was not at all his will to come now. He will come when he has opportunity.
13  Be watchful, stand firm in the faith, act like men, be strong.  14  Let all that you do be done in love.
15  Now I urge you, brothers—you know that the household of Stephanas were the first converts in Achaia, and that they have devoted themselves to the service of the saints—  16  be subject to such as these, and to every fellow worker and laborer.  17  I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because they have made up for your absence,  18  for they refreshed my spirit as well as yours. Give recognition to such people.
19  The churches of Asia send you greetings. Aquila and Prisca, together with the church in their house, send you hearty greetings in the Lord.  20  All the brothers send you greetings. Greet one another with a holy kiss.

26  For consider your calling, brothers: not many of you were wise according to worldly standards, not many were powerful, not many were of noble birth.  27  But God chose what is foolish in the world to shame the wise; God chose what is weak in the world to shame the strong;  28  God chose what is low and despised in the world, even things that are not, to bring to nothing things that are,  29  so that no human being might boast in the presence of God.  30  And because of him you are in Christ Jesus, who became to us wisdom from God, righteousness and sanctification and redemption,  31  so that, as it is written, “Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.”
What does the passage tell us about wisdom? God’s wisdom? Earthly wisdom?
19 - God destroys the wisdom of the wise
20 - God makes foolish the wisdom of the world
21 - God cannot be known only through earthly intellect and wisdom**
25 - God’s wisdom is on a completely different tier than human wisdom
30 - Jesus becomes to us wisdom from God; Jesus is our source of God’s wisdom
**Maybe briefly follow up asking about how we can know God. Knowing God through both intellect and experience. And exploring the weaknesses of only having one or the other.
Why is Christ crucified a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Greeks?
Verse 22 tells us what each group desired. For the Jews, a prophet or savior dying isn’t any significant sign since he’d be just a man. Also, Jesus dying on the cross (or a ‘tree’) is something that is cursed according to Deuteronomy. There’s no way the savior would be cursed.
For the Gentiles, since they’re about intellect and wisdom, it makes no sense to find power in a crucified criminal.
Why does God choose to use the weak to shame the strong/foolish to shame the wise?
So that no human would boast in the presence of God (v29). It is how God shows his exclusive power, and reminds human beings of their need for God. The reversal of our typical expectation of power allows God’s power to shine. We can refer to many, many stories throughout scripture.
How have we seen this in real life?
Have an example in mind, whether in your own life or seen in someone else’s life where God used the weakness for something greater. NOTE: Doesn’t necessarily have to be at the ‘expense’ of someone strong/wise.
What makes it hard to embrace our weakness? How can we embrace our weakness?
We don’t want to feel inferior or powerless. We feel better about ourselves when we know we’re better than (at the expense of) someone else. Weakness also makes us feel like we’re not in control. We’re also taught that strength and pride are high virtues.
We embrace our weakness with humility. This is done by looking at Christ who is the ultimate example of humility. The one who had all power empties himself of power in order to serve mankind.
**This question is to challenge our idea of weakness. We hear about this at church frequently, but we don’t actually embrace our weakness in real life. We, by default, seek to be self-sufficient and not acknowledge our need for God.

Things prepared by God for those who love him (9-10)

Things that have been freely given to us by God (12)

What issue is Paul addressing in this passage?
There are two groups that Paul is addressing. One who thinks it’s fine to eat food offered to idols and one that does not. This is leading to disagreement with each group thinking they are correct/better. Note that this is not a black and white issue.

Look at the ends of this section of scripture, what phrase repeats?
“Intention of man’s thoughts were evil” - 6:5 and 8:21
This serves as the bookend of our chiasm. As a group, try and identify the chiasm.
Look at the numbers. Probably best to have part of the group look from the top and the other look from the bottom to list out the numbers. Once you have a list, see if a pattern can be found. The relevant numbers are ones about duration (as opposed to age, date, etc).
Where is the center?  8:1 “But God remembered Noah…”
Why is this strange as the center? Did God somehow forget about Noah? What is significant about this being the center? What does it tell us about God?
No need to ask all of these questions at once. Later questions can be follow up questions.
If this is the center of the chiasm, what is the focus of Noah’s story?
We want to establish that Noah’s story is not primarily about judgment, but about mercy. God’s remembrance of Noah signifies God’s faithfulness and love to his people. Typically, we talk about how the world was evil and God was out to punish (therefore don’t be bad/sinful). Emphasis is on God’s character and wanting to restore mankind and creation.
(optional) What does the text describe following the center? Does it sound familiar to something else in Genesis?
God remembers Noah and begins the restoration process with receding water. This restoration of creation parallels the Genesis creation account. Don’t need to get too technical with this.
8:1 Wind/spirit over the earth, 8:6 open window for light, waters receding, land reappearing, animals are back, etc.
APPS:
Why is God ‘remembering’ so important for us as Christians?
God remembering means he hasn’t abandoned us, especially when it comes to providing salvation through Christ. Also for times of suffering and times when we forget about God.
What happens when we forget about these truths? How often do we forget? How can we remember more frequently?

Open  Genesis 9:18-29
Look at the details in this passage. What are some problems/questions in the passage? What things don’t make sense?
Spend time here. We will be tempted to just gloss over the words and details. Passage is short enough for a deep dive. Like previous weeks, worth to have a shared place to write them down as they are shared.
What are some possible explanations for Noah’s reaction? Why curse Canaan?
Castration thus curse on Ham’s descendents since Noah would not be able to have more kids.
Maybe Noah just plain angry about being seen naked in shame.
Noah just in a drunk tirade?
How does Leviticus 18:1-10 provide some insight to Noah?
Read enough of Leviticus to get a sense for what it’s saying. Terminology of ‘uncovering nakedness’ is a sexual innuendo. Soft conclusion in that Ham raped his mother based on Leviticus. This gives rationale for Noah’s reaction in cursing Ham/Canaan.
Who has done the “cursing” so far in Genesis? So what is Noah essentially doing in this situation? (or who is Noah trying to be?)
This “cursing” is only done by God (so far with Adam/Eve and Cain). Noah is the first (and only) human to use this word. As God cursed Adam/Eve in early Genesis, Noah is taking this role of God in cursing Canaan.
APPS:
When do we try to usurp authority and be God in our lives? Why do we naturally want to do this?
Obviously try and be specific; share personal experiences/struggles. For the ‘why’ part, don’t just answer with “because we’re sinful.” Flesh that out more with the specific reasons for MY desire to be God.
Why should we care about allowing God to be God in our lives?
This question is worth wrestling with. We know God should be God, but is there an advantage to it? Is it just because the Bible says so (not very motivating)? Wouldn’t it be easier/better to let me be God? Worth asking ourselves as we lead this question.
How do we deal with these desires? How can they be prevented?

Read Genesis 10:32-11:9
What have we learned previously about this story?
Get a general sense of how we view the story. Generally a negative view of the story as a punishment. This is just a warm up question.
What are some problems or questions that arise from this passage?
As per usual, look at certain details that we may not have noticed. Maybe we’ve gotten too familiar with this story.
E.g. Is there something wrong with settling or building a tower?
Does God prefer wandering?
Does God have to ‘come down’ in order to see what they’re doing?
Why do the humans build the city and tower?
We usually learn that they have pride in wanting to make a name, but v4 says otherwise. They do it to prevent getting dispersed. Maybe inquire as to why they’d be fearful of getting dispersed?
So why does God confuse their language?
(This question is related to the previous).  Not a curse! No hint of God being angry or vengeful. Almost seems like God is threatened by man’s progress. But this confusion forces them to disperse to different parts of the world… which leads to differing cultures and people groups. Even though humans were doing what they could to prevent this outcome, God orchestrates this diversity.
With diversity in language/culture, what does it force humans to do to achieve things?
Work harder to understand one another. Takes time to see the perspective of others and understand them.
APPS:
Why is taking time to understand one another so important within the church?
Conflict easily arises when we don’t. Loving one another comes hand in hand with truly knowing each other.
When have we failed to understand one another? When have I felt not understood?
Not sure how open people will be with this but it’s an important question as we work towards better loving one another.

What false story or narrative do I buy into that prevents me from resting?
Although we affirm gospel truths, in our day to day we functionally believe something else. Some of these false beliefs prevent us from resting (value in productivity, God or others will think less of me if I don’t “do” or produce, resting is lazy or opposite of hardwork)
How can I incorporate rest into my weekly routine?

Genesis 11:27-32
Warm up: Why does God choose Abram?
1) Map out the family tree of all of the characters in the passage. What do you notice? Anything strange?
Find a way to share screen. MS Paint?
2) Knowing the status of women during this time and women in genealogies, why is Iscah mentioned?
Don’t need to spend too long here. Iscah has no business in this genealogy. She’s not one of the sons, nor is she the son of Haran. Milcah reappears in the story later on, Iscah does not. You probably won’t come to a solid answer here, but this question is to brainstorm different theories. But we know that there’s a reason for her mention. The author would not just add a woman in a genealogy for no reason.
3) Look at Gen 9:23 and Gen 11:29 (ESV is needed). In Hebrew, in both verses, “took” is singular. What does this imply for the passages?
Both people involved in the action are seen as one; they act as one. But the first person mentioned is the one that gets the credit (order of names matter in ancient Israel).
Follow up question:  How would characterize Shem’s decision/action in Gen 9?
Establishing that it’s a kind/gracious act for Noah to cover his shame. Likewise, with the weird grammar, we can assume that Gen 11 is also referring to a kind/gracious act.
4) Consider 1) “Iscah” in a Mesopotamian tongue kind of sounds like “little queen” or “princess” and 2) Genesis 20:12. What is a possible explanation for the identity of Iscah?
Sarai and Iscah are possibly the same person.
5) Why is Abram marrying Iscah/Sarai such a big deal? What does it show us about Abram?
She is left on her own without a husband; no power, no status, no livelihood.
She’s barren. Abram willingly takes a wife who cannot have children, which is a big deal in his time when lineage was super important.
Also, when he comes up with the idea to ‘take wives’ with Nahor, Abram, as first born, willingly takes the barren daughter. Note that both are taking care of the daughters of their late brother.
Abram is willingly selfless and self sacrificing.
APPS:
Is it easier to sacrifice for others or for God?  Super safe question. Skip if not needed.
What parts of life am I slow or unwilling to sacrifice?
Where is God calling me to be selfless or self sacrificing this week?
What makes it hard to be selfless or self sacrificing? How can we be more selfless?
Latter three questions are somewhat similar. Adjust them to your group to see which one fits the best. I would encourage concrete answers and challenge everyone to actually take practical steps in this direction with the ‘how’.

Read Genesis 12:1-13:4
Warm up: Going to Egypt during famine was very common. Why would Egypt be the place to go during a famine?
More of a cultural background question. Typically, we imagine Egypt to be a huge desert with pyramids… but the Nile is there. The Nile gives year-round access to water and crops during the dry and rainy season (no four seasons there). Going to Egypt meant access to food regardless of season.
Describe the plan of Abram (+Sarai)? What is the motivation (look at v13)?
It’s important to note the cultural expectations regarding courtship/marriage/relationships. By saying Sarai is his non-married sister, potential suitors need to come bring gifts to win the bid for Sarai. This is a way for Abram and Sarai to gain wealth. Typically, we’ve solely blamed Abram for using his wife, but v13 shows that his desire is for Sarai’s sake. Abram, as the patriarch, needs to be able to provide for his wife and his household. So perhaps Sarai was in on it but at the very least Abram is not being completely selfish.
Is Abram justified in carrying out this plan?
Discuss some of the tensions. It somewhat feels Robinhood-esque in doing something morally grey to help people. Also add on that this is supposed to be a man of God who is using deception for gain.
What goes wrong? Was the plan successful?
Pharaoh takes in Sarai. Pharaoh does not need to go through the same channels as other suitors; he can just take. Abram and Sarai are placed in a potentially dangerous situation. But we see God still protecting Abram (v17) and they still left Egypt with massive wealth (13:2).
APPS
What do we learn about man’s plans through Abram/Sarai?  Scuffed… sometimes
How should we view human planning in light of God’s larger plan?  Safe, theological question. We obviously want to move to more personal responses with MY plans.
When (or in what situations) do I find myself trusting my plans more than God’s plan? What should I do in these cases?
Why can/should I trust God?
The Apps progressively get more personal. Adjust for your group as needed. I would encourage groups to be honest about struggles in trusting God and be honest about where we desire to have control of life. Depending on your group, you might need to help people identify that they desire control in life.

Warm up: Review Lot’s relationship to Abram.
What are the three (3) promises to Abram in Genesis 12:1-3. Knowing Abram’s family situation, what’s the problem with one of these promises?
Land, Blessing, Posterity. If Sarai is barren, posterity cannot happen. They cannot have children.
If you were Abram in this circumstance with the same promise, what would you do to fix the situation?
Small brainstorm in seeing Abram’s POV. We want to see that Abram’s in a conundrum of sorts. No “correct” answer.
Keep these ideas in mind as you read the passage.
Read Genesis 13:1-18
Why do Lot and Abram separate? Why is this a big deal in light of the story so far? Why did Abram take Lot with him in the first place?
The land was too crowded and caused issues between Abram’s people and Lot’s people. Lot was Abram’s solution to the problem of having children. Sarai was barren so Abram planned to have offspring through Lot, who was still as relative. If Lot leaves, then Abram has no solution to the promise of having children.
Gen 15:2, Gen 16 are other examples where Abram/Sarai find someone else to bear children to solve the problem.
What do we learn about Abram as he initiates this separation?
Abram shows hints of greater trust in God’s plan and story. One could argue that the fighting forced his hand, but he selflessly gives Lot the option of land (even though Abram has dibs as the older male). It’s also no surprise that the Lord reassures Abram of the promise after Lot departs.
APPS
What difficulties come with submitting to God’s story?
Where does/has God wanted me to submit to his story over my own? When have I tried to trust my story over God’s story?
Do I consider God’s story in my life or do I just default to my own?

Intro cultural covenant practices
Read Genesis 15. Recall the three parts of God’s promise to Abram (refer to ch 12).
Land, Blessing, Posterity
What’s Abram’s concern in v2? How does God respond?
Abram is again wrestling with not being able to have a son for posterity. He essentially questions God and “offers” another relative to help establish his line. After v2, God is silent. Abram has to reiterate the question. In Hebrew, since both v2 and v3 begin with “Abram said,” it implies that some time has passed between the two verses. Might be worth to wrestle with why God would want to be silent with Abram at v2.
According to cultural practices, what is supposed to happen after v9-10? What does Abram do instead? Why?
Abram is supposed to walk through the animals to seal the deal. Notice that Abram does not walk through the animals. In fact, he waits long enough for predators to smell and find the carcasses. Abram definitely knew what was expected in this covenant since it was cultural practice. He probably knew that he would not be able to keep up his end in a covenant with God and therefore didn’t want to get cut in half.
Look at v17. In Israel’s story, where and when do fire and smoke appear? What does this event mean in light of this covenant practice?
Fire and smoke are representative of the presence of God (pillar of fire/smoke in the desert, smoke filing the tabernacle). God walks through the animal halves by himself. It is a one-sided covenant meaning God will take on the punishment regardless of who messes up keeping the covenant.
APPS:
Why does God sometimes choose to be silent with us (as he does with Abram)?
This application refers to the first question. This is a real struggle for Christians. Is God really there? Does he really care? Why does nothing seem to happen when I pray? Worth to voice out these inner struggles and encourage one another through them.
God is willing to take on these burdens/punishments on our behalf (*cough* Jesus). What implications does this have in our day to day? In our workplaces? In our relationships with people?
Thinking specifically is best here. This grace is something we can appreciate as Christians in a general, abstract sense, but how does this reality actually affect us? Surely it’s more than just saving us from hell...

READ Gen 18:1-15
What has just happened preceding this chapter? Why would Abraham be hanging out outside?
Since we skipped some chapters, this is just to get some context. Abraham just received the covenant of circumcision. Meaning he just performed these circumcisions on all the men, a break well deserved.
Look at the passage closely. What questions or interesting things stand out?
Three men representing singular God, why does God choose to appear and speak this way, how does Abraham figure out it is God...
In Abraham and Sarah’s eyes, who are these three men initially?
There’s no sign of the three men being God at first. Verse 1 is something that the author already knows, not necessarily what Abraham knows. They were just three men to them initially. We can also tell by Abraham addressing them as ‘Lord’ (lowercase). When ‘Lord’ refers to God it’s in all caps like v1, 10.
How does Abraham treat these guests? Why does Abraham react the way he does to these guests?
Extreme generosity. He gives them a ton of bread cakes and prepares a feast for the guests. Remember that Abraham prepares the feast before any hint of the guests being God. Abraham displaying super hospitality and selflessness.

Who are the unseen, fringe, or marginalized in my life?

Read  slowly and critically  Genesis 22:1-19
What are some questions or strange things in this story?
Seems strange for God to make Abraham sacrifice the promised child… what about the promise of posterity? Abraham doesn’t make a fuss, even though he’s questioned God before. Isaac doesn’t object?
What’s probably going through the minds of Abraham and Isaac?
Don’t need to spend too long here. We just want to emphasize the narrative-ness of this account and how these guys were actual humans who did not know the whole picture. Definite anxiety and sadness with what they were commanded to do.
Review the Hagar and Ishmael story (21:8-20). What parallels do you see?
“Morning” 21:14, 22:3

Remember that the Israelites are receiving this story at Sinai. What’s significant for them about a father saying “Here I am”? Especially in comparison to the Hagar story?

Read Genesis 24:1-28

Comprehension question to set up the story.

Water for him and the camels. Watering camels is not an easy task. They utilize a lot of water. Estimates say that it takes 10 trips into a well to water a camel (the well/cistern isn’t simply dropping a bucket, a person goes down into this place to get water). 10 camels means ~100 trips.

Week 1: Introduction + Servanthood/Selflessness
Do a friendly icebreaker… anything works
On topic icebreaker: List the top 3 guests (or group of guests) you’d be most comfortable hosting at your place. Why?
Read Genesis 18:1-15, 19:1-14
Who shows hospitality in these passages? To whom? How do they show it?
Comprehension: Abraham and Lot show hospitality to the guests who turn out to be angels. Abraham uses a lot of ingredients to make a feast and offers to help them wash their feet. Lot convinces the guests to stay for the night and also prepares a feast for them. Also, in a quite uncomfortable way, Lot is willing to give up his daughters for the sake of these guests. (quick note that Lot does not know that the guests will blind the Sodomites when he offers up his daughters)
What is the result of allowing these individuals into their homes?
More comprehension: Abraham (and Sarah) receive a reminder of the promised child, remember that a lot of time has passed since they first received the promise. Lot gets protection by the guests, both in the immediate human threat and also the judgment on Sodom.
Would it have been better or worse to let the guests pass by?
Pretty much an opinion question. Generally we see that positive things came out of having these guests over.
What did it take for Abraham and Lot to show hospitality to their guests?
We’re looking for things that they sacrificed to show hospitality. Time, energy, resources, ingredients, comfort, Lot’s daughters, security...
What things are we not willing to give up for the sake of hospitality?
This is looking for specific things, many of which will be similar to the list above. A simple follow up question is how they would prefer to use their ______ (time, energy, resources, etc).
Is what we see in Abraham and Lot even worth trying to imitate today?
This is a reality check for us. We clearly see the extreme selflessness and sacrifice of Abraham and Lot. Is it just a nice sounding tale? Or is it something we’re actually supposed to imitate? Hopefully at this point, we see our inner conflict -- we know we should imitate but we cannot or, more accurately,  do not want  to. I’m sure for some members, their personal view of scripture will cause them to not care and not be conflicted, that’s fine for now.
So what is the biggest barrier? [What are we supposed to do about it? Do we just shrug and carry on?]
Hopefully we come to the conclusion that  selfishness  is the biggest barrier. We sometimes make the excuse that “culturally” it’s different today, i.e. there are more dangers nowadays. But it’s more like we’ve been culturally influenced to trust people less (not to mention that Lot’s welcoming of the guests did not put him in a “safe” situation). We make it seem like it’s “unrealistic” nowadays but arguably we are just more unwilling to make sacrifices.
**We’re looking to point out our complacency and inner conflict with selfishness. If we know we should be selfless, do we actually desire to grow in this area even when it’s difficult?
If you have time, pray for selflessness in areas of life.

Week 2: The Stranger
Icebreaker: Share a time when you have received hospitality?
Feel free to do a fun icebreaker in addition to this on-topic one.
Read  (carefully)  Judges 6:11-24, Judges 13:1-21
Point out some similarities between the two stories.
This is to help us get familiar with the stories. They aren’t the most popular ones that people will know off the top of their heads. Some examples: Both are ‘weak’ in their group, encounter marks the beginning of some sort of calling or work from God, hosting the guests, feast for the guests.
Who shows hospitality in these passages? How do they show it? What is significant about the food they choose?
Comprehension: Gideon and Manoah showing hospitality by providing a feast, giving up time and energy for these guests. They go all out on the feast, using a young goat which is reserved for celebration (you can think about the Prodigal Son story). It’s an expensive sacrifice for these guests.
What do they know about their guests as the stories progress?
In both cases, the guests are strangers. The hosts have no idea that they are angels of the Lord. It’s only after they do some divine or supernatural act where they realize the guests’ identities (fire + vanishing).
How would they respond differently if they knew initially that the Lord visited them?
A feast would have been the absolute minimum. Their response would have more reverence. Arguably we can see their reaction based on what they do at the end of the accounts when they discover the truth.
What kind of hesitancies come when considering hosting a stranger? [Did Gideon and Manoah (and Abraham and Lot) face these issues?]
More personal question and bringing this idea to real life. Hesitancies of safety, not wanting to sacrifice _____ (time, money, etc), general discomfort, not feeling like we have the most impressive home… The follow up question is to help establish that the Bible characters aren’t that different from us. They would also feel similar hesitancies even though the culture is different.
Consider Leviticus 19:33-34 in combination with these stories, what are we supposed to do today?
This question is to help us identify the conflict between what we see in scripture and how we approach the idea of ‘strangers’ in our lives. We can make all the excuses that we want, but scripture is clear through commands and examples of what we’re supposed to do. Do we just shrug at our disobedience? Does it even bother us that our lives don’t come close to this command? Groups can dabble in considering how this should look in our lives today.
Bonus if you have time: Who do we see as a “stranger”?

Widow of Zarephath is very poor; she’s about to give up on life. She basically has nothing to give in her situation. The Shunammite woman is wealthy and is able to give with abundance. Though she is rich, she has no son or heir (poor in a different way). Both women still host the prophet.
What sacrifices were made by the women to show hospitality?
Financial sacrifices - although one sacrifice was MUCH harder than the other. Time and effort to feed the prophet or build the room.
Why would they choose to show hospitality in their situations? [What are their attitudes in showing hospitality?]
Widow arguably “had” to based on verse 9. But she still made a choice to obey even though she already made a resolve that she was going to die so maybe dragging her feet to serve Elijah? The wife was very eager to show hospitality. She was egging her husband on to make these accommodations for Elisha.
What do Elijah and Elisha learn about the respective women during their stays? What gets “exposed” about them?
Widow’s lacking wealth gets exposed, Elijah doesn’t know that God told such a woman to feed him. Elisha finds out that the woman does not have a child and the husband is old. Culturally, it’s taboo for her to not have a son (no heir). Both situations are potential sources of shame.
What kind of things can people find out about us when we show hospitality?
Cleanliness, family dynamics, house habits… Longer guests stay the more they learn about your personality or how you really act towards guests. Masks and fronts are at risk when showing hospitality.
How do we typically guard ourselves from getting exposed? Why do we do this?
Pivot question from talking about exposure of physical home hospitality to emotional/spiritual vulnerability. Ultimately we want to relate the idea of hospitality to vulnerability. Providing examples would be effective in getting us to think this way.
What does it take for us to be vulnerable?
We all have different barriers that prevent us from being vulnerable. Different people will therefore have different requirements that will allow us to be more willing to be vulnerable. No need to neatly round this out; the group teaching will cover the “hope” side of things.

Things talked about in previous weeks. Just want to give a reminder on what we’ve discussed. Examples: Security, comfort, time, money, interacting with less familiar people...

Read Luke 5:12-32
Who are the people Jesus interacts with? What are their social statuses?
Leper - has a contagious skin disease, outcast in society, literally lives outside the city away from others, lives around other lepers, not to touch/interact with anyone else, culturally supposed to announce to people they’re getting close so others walk away
Paralytic - no way to contribute to society, destined for abandonment and/or death, no means or hope of healing, cultural belief was that him or his parents did something to deserve this
Levi/Tax Collector - low in social status, these Jews essentially worked for the Roman government, often were scammers by over-taxing people, seen as traitors
What do you notice about Jesus’ interactions with the different characters?
Jesus is intentional to show care for these marginalized groups. He’s willing to draw near to them even when it’s culturally inappropriate (especially with the contagious leper, sharing food with sinners). Jesus is also willing to be interrupted by these people. His schedule as the Messiah is thrown out the window when these random people enter his sphere. Mixture of Jesus being approached and moving towards these people; he initiates the care for all of them.
How does this translate to how we are to interact with people? What about in relation to hospitality my
?
We should be willing to get close to others, even if they seem less desirable in our minds. How often do we just exclusively gravitate to the people we feel comfortable with? We should also be willing to make time to care and be hospitable to others. Weekday meetups or hosting can seem inconvenient in our packed schedules. Just generally, we should try to actually see people.
How does Jesus show hospitality without actually having a home?
Logistically he used other locations, but we see Jesus continuously practicing the core of hospitality which is care. We also see Jesus feeding people in other episodes.
How does Jesus show hospitality to us?
His death and resurrection brings us into the family of God. The spiritual concept of adoption makes us more than just guests in the Kingdomb but heirs. Jesus brings us in, sees us for who we are, and cares for us.

Due to their disobedience, God now promises not to drive the Canaanites out such that Israel will not enjoy the blessing. Instead, the Canaanites will be a thorn and snare (v3).
Tension is how God can lovingly bless his people but also needs to justly punish sin/disobedience.
In other words,  God is saying: You have put me in an impossible situation. I have sworn to bless you as my beloved people, and sworn not to bless you as disobedient people. I have promised to love you as my people; but I have also promised that I will judge sin.
Read Romans 3:23-26 and 2 Corinthians 5:21. How did God solve the tension, so that he could be both just and forgiving to his people?
On the cross, God’s love and justice are complete. Our sin is given to Jesus and his righteousness is given to us. His wrath is satisfied in Christ, but also his love is displayed since he can now accept and forgive us.
Read Judges 2:6 - 3:6  - Gather any questions from people
The death of Joshua is recorded twice in the book of Judges (1:1; 2:6–10). What is the significance of his death, and the death of that whole generation, for understanding the book of Judges?
Joshua represents the Israelites who were obedient to God. Joshua led those people and his direct generation followed him. With the loss of this generation and the loss of Joshua as a leader, Israel drifted away. This drifting continues all throughout the book of Judges.
What cycle in Israelite history do verses 10-21 summarize? Draw the image on the whiteboard and go through this together.

5- God raises a judge ; 6- Peace ; 7- Judge dies

How do we see each stage of the “Judges cycle” in Othniel’s story?

General cycle:
1- People rebel ; 2- God is angry ; 3- Israel oppressed by enemies ; 4- Distress/cry out
5- God raises a judge ; 6- Peace ; 7- Judge dies
Read Judges 3 v 12-31  - Gather any questions
How does Ehud’s story fit into the Judges cycle ?
Same cycle of doing evil (v12), God angry and given to an enemy (v12-14), Israel cries out (v15), God sends judge (v15), judge battles and wins (v28-30)
But how does Ehud’s weakness enable him to defeat Israel’s enemy?
Sword on right thigh under clothes versus typical sword-wearing (v16). No one is checking the “incorrect” side for a weapon. He looks weak/harmless and presents as no threat and the king sends the guards away. Ehud is unique in being able to eliminate the king without guards around.
According to  Isaiah 53:2-6 , h ow is Ehud a preview of the Lord Jesus? According to  1 Corinthians 1:26-29 , h ow is Ehud a preview of every follower of the Lord Jesus?
Jesus had “no form or majesty that we should look at him.” His humble and ‘weak’ form allowed him to rescue humanity. Only Jesus was able to carry out this plan..
God chooses those who are  foolish, weak, lowly  to carry out his work. God is not dependent on our human ability and uses people at the margins. Salvation comes from God because we are weak and ‘left handed’.
What does it look like for us to be “left handed”?
**Left-handed is synonymous to weakness
NOTE: weakness is not synonymous to sin. This distinction is important as we identify our weaknesses.
Shyness, not liking public speaking, financially, family situations, current circumstantial struggles, fear of judgment
How is knowing that we are “left handed” humbling?
Reminds us that we’re not God; we weak and need to lean on God
Admitting weakness allows us to be vulnerable and practice mutual support
Even at our best, we are still weak in reference to God and not in control
Any work is done through us by God, as if God works despite our weakness
How is knowing that we are “left handed” freeing?
God is not judging us by our strength
We can forgive ourselves in our weakness
We can be more deeply seen by others; no need to hide
Allows us to boldly serve and step out in faith
Our weakness becomes something God can use instead of it being a hinderance

Read Judges 4 v 1-24  - Gather any questions
How do we see the Judges cycle in Deborah’s story?
1- Did evil (v1) ; 2- God angry ; 3- God sold them to Jabin (v2) ; 4- Cries out (v3); 5- God raises up Deborah (v4); 6- Peace (5:31) ; 7- Deborah dies at some point

5- God raises a judge ; 6- Peace ; 7- Judge dies
How is Deborah’s cycle different from Othniel and Ehud?
Female
Deborah is also a prophetess (v4)
She has a courtroom (v5)
She doesn’t actually go and fight - but she is the ruler
How do we interpret Barak’s request to Deborah in v8?
Groups will probably start with this interpretation: There are two ways of understanding Deborah and Barak’s conversation in verses 6-9.  One is that in verse 8, Barak is lacking faith - and so although Deborah agrees to go with him (v9), he won’t get the honor for the victory because of his timid lack of faith in God’s promise and command.
Read/consider Hebrews 11:32-34. Hebrews gives faith kudos to Barak. How does this fit with Judges 4?
Barak is actually showing faith by asking Deborah, God’s spokesperson, to go with him. He recognizes her authority and believes she can provide further guidance on the battlefield. Also he embraces the fact that in verse 9, Deborah is saying:  “On the expedition you are taking, the honor will not be yours.”  She is making a statement about his future, not giving a verdict on his faith.
Barak’s faith:
“What aspect of faith does Barak show in v8?”’
He recognizes he need God’s guidance -  listening to God
Since Deborah is God’s representative, it’s wise for Barak to have her with him in battle
“What aspect of faith does Barak show in v13-14?”
He demonstrates  courage  despite the disadvantage
Canaanites have better technology, remember iron chariots from Ch 1
“What aspect of faith does Barak show in v9?”
He knows he won’t get honor - showing  humility
He embraces the message that a women, not him as commander, will receive glory
How does Deborah’s prophecy in verse 9 come true? [if your group is early, you can discuss about the moral ambiguity of Jael killing Sisera such a crazy way – this will be explored next week anyways]
Jael, wife of Heber the Kenite, kills a fleeing Sisera. So it isn’t Deborah, but Jael who receives the glory and honor
In what areas do we need to exercise Barak-like faith today?
Try and spend time here. Faith is an active thing, not just belief. Barak gives us an example of the practical aspects that come with demonstrating faith. Think about different situations in our lives. More specificity and specific situations can help with answering this question (i.e. sharing gospel in places, inviting people to YAR8/church, making ‘less logical’ choices as God wants, going on missions while working, etc)

Vision: To recognize God’s greater narrative in our lives.
Read Judges 5:1-31  - Gather any questions
Review the events of Deborah and Barak from last week.
What’s your reaction to what Jael did (4:18-22)? What was good and bad about what she did?
She killed the main enemy of God’s people. She showed bravery and that she was on God’s side. As a Kenite, she aligned with Israel. But her actions are, by definition, sin: lying and killing. In addition, she breaks the cultural rules of hospitality (remember Abraham). In a way, it seems like she abused the hospitality culture of that time.
How does 5:24 describe her? What does this mean?
“Most blessed”. Her actions were approved of in the greater narrative of God’s story. It is a testament to God’s sovereignty in utilizing everything, including sin, to carry out his purposes.
How do we reconcile this with Jesus’ command to love our enemies?
Lean into the tension here and allow the group to wrestle with this. See how members think about this since it’s such a clear contradiction. Perhaps explore the implications of this tension for Christians in the 21st century.
How does this chapter picture the battle between Barak’s men and Sisera’s forces (v4-5, 19-22)?
God went with them and showed his power through nature (v4). God sent rain and earthquakes (v20) - the river flooded (v21).
How does God’s involvement lead to  why Sisera and his army were defeated?
Rain and wet ground would be bad for chariots. Would have been unwise for Sisera to battle in those rainy conditions if he knew of them.
What happens when we have only a Judges-4  “surface-level” perspective on our lives, and forget to combine it with a Judges-5 “theological” perspective?  Why is it easy to do this?
Note: The quotations around “theological” are important. It doesn’t mean that we are somehow less theological if we don’t have a Judges-5 perspective. “Theological” is just a label to compare with “surface-level”.
Failing to see the ‘theological’ perspective means we don’t see God's hand at work around us. We forget God’s involvement and he becomes more distant; we simply forget the supernatural exists. We end up over-honoring ourselves in success and over-despairing in struggles. Having a ‘theological’ mindset allows us to praise God for what we see him doing as well as trust him when we can’t explicitly see him moving. It allows us to trust. We easily forget this because our sinful nature makes us see what is right in front of us, including ourselves. We end up biased to honor ourselves and worship things other than God. We are God instead.

Read Judges 6:1-10
What is different in this cycle:
with the oppression (vv. 1-6)?
Israel forced to leave home and live in the mountains. The Midianites exploited any crop of Israel leaving them starving.
with how God responds to the Israelites crying out to him (vv. 7-10)?
God sends a prophet, not a judge. The people need to hear some truth before getting rescued; the prophet reminds them of what God has done and what they have done – disobeyed.
Why do the people need a prophet before they have a rescuer? What’s the real reason why Israel is crying out to God?
Israel isn’t really sorry. They don’t like being oppressed by Midian but they are not repentant– not sorry for disobeying God. They are only upset at the result of their sin, the oppression.
Before Israel can appreciate rescue, they need to know why they need rescuing. God wants Israel to understand that their idolatry and sin has led them to their current state.
Israel clearly is not repentant, but do they regret their mistake? What’s the difference between regret and repentance? (refer to 2 Cor 7:10 if needed: “ For godly grief produces a repentance that leads to salvation without regret, whereas worldly grief produces death.”)
Just have a discussion about this topic. Encourage people to share thoughts and wrestle with the differences/similarities. No need to land at the “right” answer. This will be covered in the large group.
Read Judges 6:11-24
When the angel of the Lord visits Gideon, how do their opinions differ on whether God has forgotten his people (vv. 13-14)?
Gideon doesn’t think the Lord is with him. He points out their situation and lack of rescue so the Lord must have abandoned Israel. The Lord assures Gideon that he has not abandoned Israel and is raising up Gideon to be the mighty warrior.
How does God view Gideon? How does Gideon view himself? How can both be true? (v12, 15)
God views Gideon as a mighty warrior. Gideon views himself as the least of his tribe. Gideon may actually be weak, but the enabling of God allows him to be a mighty warrior. God equips the people he wants to use; not necessarily choosing those who are already ‘strong’ or able.
How does the dual truth of 1) Gideon being a mighty warrior and 2) the least of this tribe apply to Christians? What happens when we forget one “side”?
Christians also see that we are weak but God empowers us to do his work. Our sinfulness gets in the way but God uses us to do what we could never do on our own. Christians are called to trust in God’s power and forgiveness when it comes to salvation and in our day to day. When we forget our sinfulness, we become over-confident and judgmental. If we forget our acceptance before God, we become anxious and guilty.
Read Judges 6:25-40
How does God command or enable Gideon to deal with: [if short on time, Jed start with B, Evan start with C, Josh start with A, Richard start with B]
the enemy among God’s people (vv. 25-32)?
There’s an altar and pole for worshiping Canaanite gods. The enemy among them is their idolatry. Gideon is to be the deliverer regarding the idols first, not their circumstance.
the enemy around God’s people (vv. 33-35)?
God equips his servants through the Holy Spirit. From there and with that strength, Gideon calls God’s people together.
the enemy within Gideon (vv. 36-40)?
Gideon struggles to believe God’s word. He’s worried that God will let him down. God enables Gideon to deal with doubt through the fleeces (is this good or bad?). Gideon is more looking to understand who God is, not necessarily get a sign, since God is relatively a stranger to Gideon at this point.

With each reading section, see if there are any questions. And be sure that everyone knows what happened and are following the story – reading comprehension!

What does God do to Gideon’s army? What lesson does God want to teach him, and Israel (v. 2)?
Army is reduced to 300. God wants Gideon and Israel to praise him for victory, not themselves. Humans naturally want to boast in themselves, seeing themselves as saviors. But God deserves the glory. By making the army 300, Israel should have no choice but to acknowledge God’s doing.

God reassures Gideon through his word by reaffirming victory to Gideon in v9
God uses the word of others to reaffirm when Gideon (happens to) listen to the dream/interpretation of an  enemy  soldier
God also uses  circumstance in bringing Gideon to the place to hear at the exact right time
V15- Gideon worships and confidently obeys God in response
How should the manner of the victory (vv. 16-23) help Gideon and Israel to trust in God, and not boast in themselves?
They didn’t do anything to win. They held their positions and yelled in the middle of the night, Midianites fled, and killed each other (v21-23).
Read Judges 8:22-8:31
Gideon knows that the only king Israel should have is the Lord, not him or his son.  But how do Gideon’s actions then not match up with his words?
V24-26 = he asks for financial reward which is something a king would do
V27 = Gideon makes an ephod, which is worn by the high priest. The high priest is the intermediary between the people and God. This act is pointing to himself where people can meet God and find guidance from God... rather than God himself or an actual priest
V29-31 = wives and concubines, a king’s habit. Also, Abimelech means “my father is king”
Is Gideon a faithful character??  See what people think. Gideon seemed to be fine at first… then lost his way
What do we learn from Gideon about the dangers of God-given success?
Success can cause us to forget God’s grace since we want to be our own savior. God-given success can make us think we’ve earned the blessing and therefore should receive honor and glory; that we are super powerful or strong. Sometimes we can start faithful but end up absorbed in the success.
What does this danger look like today for us? At work or school?
Think about at work or school when we put so much stock in our performance. Or when we find ourselves idolizing our advancements and success. It’s easy for us to forget that God is involved in these places and in our successes at work or school. We take it as our own effort and own effort alone.
Possible follow up …When our happiness and identity are completely wrapped up in our success, what happens?

25  And behold, a lawyer stood up to put him to the test, saying, “Teacher, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?”  26  He said to him, “What is written in the Law? How do you read it?”  27  And he answered, “You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself.”  28  And he said to him, “You have answered correctly; do this, and you will live.”
29  But he, desiring to justify himself, said to Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”  30  Jesus replied, “A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he fell among robbers, who stripped him and beat him and departed, leaving him half dead.  31  Now by chance a priest was going down that road, and when he saw him he passed by on the other side.  32  So likewise a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.  33  But a Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to where he was, and when he saw him, he had compassion.  34  He went to him and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own animal and brought him to an inn and took care of him.  35  And the next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper, saying, ‘Take care of him, and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I come back.’  36  Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among the robbers?”  37  He said, “The one who showed him mercy.” And Jesus said to him, “You go, and do likewise.”

Expectations around hospitality
Bread usually baked daily and around enough to meet the day’s need
Visitors expected to be treated very hospitably, generally no one would turn away someone, especially not a friend
Abba
Connotations of what this word means as the 1st word of the Lord’s prayer
Prayer actually begins with “Abba”, not “Our”
A term of endearment usually first used by children towards their fathers and would continue to be used to refer to them as they grew older
Hallowed
A term used to describe something that is sacred, or set apart as holy
Our God
Reflects a communal aspect of prayer
