11  And he said, “There was a man who had two sons.  12  And the younger of them said to his father, ‘Father, give me the share of property that is coming to me.’ And he divided his property between them.  13  Not many days later, the younger son gathered all he had and took a journey into a far country, and there he squandered his property in reckless living.  14  And when he had spent everything, a severe famine arose in that country, and he began to be in need.  15  So he went and hired himself out to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him into his fields to feed pigs.  16  And he was longing to be fed with the pods that the pigs ate, and no one gave him anything.
17  “But when he came to himself, he said, ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have more than enough bread, but I perish here with hunger!  18  I will arise and go to my father, and I will say to him, “Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.  19  I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Treat me as one of your hired servants.”’  20  And he arose and came to his father. But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and felt compassion, and ran and embraced him and kissed him.  21  And the son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’  22  But the father said to his servants, ‘Bring quickly the best robe, and put it on him, and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on his feet.  23  And bring the fattened calf and kill it, and let us eat and celebrate.  24  For this my son was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found.’ And they began to celebrate.
25  “Now his older son was in the field, and as he came and drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing.  26  And he called one of the servants and asked what these things meant.  27  And he said to him, ‘Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he has received him back safe and sound.’  28  But he was angry and refused to go in. His father came out and entreated him,  29  but he answered his father, ‘Look, these many years I have served you, and I never disobeyed your command, yet you never gave me a young goat, that I might celebrate with my friends.  30  But when this son of yours came, who has devoured your property with prostitutes, you killed the fattened calf for him!’  31  And he said to him, ‘Son, you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.  32  It was fitting to celebrate and be glad, for this your brother was dead, and is alive; he was lost, and Is found.’”
Questions:
Who are the characters in this parable?
Father, older son, younger son, servants
What did the son do once he was gifted with his inheritance? What happened afterwards?
Journeyed to a far country
Squandered his money in reckless living
There was a famine
Became a hired hand
So starved he was wishing he could eat the pig food
Why did he decide to return to his father? What was his attitude upon his return?
Came to the realization that his father has money and his servants were kept in a better condition than his current one
He acknowledged his mistake and was willing to come back as a servant, not as a son
What is the reaction of the father when he sees his son return? How about the older son? Why do you think they reacted in these ways?
Welcomed his son back with joy and thanksgiving
The son was upset that he was faithful and not rewarded as well (in his own mind)
The father recognized that his younger son was lost/dead, and his return meant he was alive again
The older son merely saw the celebration and compared it to his own experiences, not recognizing that his status of living had been high this whole time as he was living under his father, whereas the son was living poorly and the fact that he was alive was worth celebrating
Whom do the father and son in this parable represent? Have you had or witnessed a “prodigal son” moment? What happened?
Father = God
Younger son = Unbelievers/those who left their faith and comes to know Christ/returns to faith.
Older son – those who follow Jesus but their hearts are still focused on themselves(?)
Judge those who were lost and now found based off their journey (sinful life)
Think of an example to share first
How does it feel knowing that God will welcome back those who stray from Him, no matter how “low” they have gone?
Should be comforting to know that He is always joyful when one of His children “come home”.
We should also celebrate and be like the father, and less like the older son (wanting recognition for “how good” we’ve been)
How can you emulate the Father’s attitude when it comes to receiving
Pre Context – Inheritance (How it works, what asking early means [rejection of father and desire to be independent], how this reflects the attitude of the son)
Post-context – Someone returning back to Jesus is worth celebrating, for their soul has been saved. Spiritually dead without Jesus, even when physically alive.

knew God’s law very well and would teach it to others (sort of)
Tax collectors
seen as traitors of the Jewish people who work for the Roman Empire to oppress and steal from the Israelites
Sinners
Occupations that are incompatible with keeping God’s commands
People known for being immoral

Who is Jesus speaking to and why is Jesus speaking to them?
Tax collectors & sinners
Actively chose to draw near
Pharisees & scribes

What are similarities and differences between the two scenarios Jesus tells in this parable?
Similarities
Losing something (of modest value but decide to not ignore)
Working hard to find, spend time
Finding it solo
Rejoicing
Telling others and rejoice together
Differences
Sheep vs coin
Shepherd vs woman
Open country vs home
Risk in losing 99 sheep vs no risk in searching stationary coins
Rejoicing in heaven over one sinner over 99 righteous vs rejoicing in presence of angels of God
Who is represented in this parable?
Shepherd & woman = Jesus
Sheep & coin = people
Lost sheep & coin = the lost, those who do not know/accept Jesus
Not lost sheep & coins = those who are already with Jesus (technically no one but Pharisees and scribes would identify with this group)
Righteous person who needs no repentance?
All have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God. We need to continuously repent too
Regardless, provides contrast to emphasize joy over saving the lost
Who are the lost? Who are the lost in your life?
Anyone who does not know Jesus
Can be coworkers, classmates, family members, friends, neighbors, etc.
Preferably ppl you have q personal connection with
What does this parable reveal about Jesus’ heart?
He desires the lost to be found (even if it’s only one)
He wholeheartedly and persistently searches for the lost, sparing no effort to find them
He cares for the lost - v 5 mentions shepherd laying sheep on shoulders when it’s found (Isaiah 49:22)
He and heaven rejoice when one sinner repents, more than 99 righteous

Being friendly, loving

Hosting and inviting people around you that you do not know as well
Consistently connecting (reflects diligence and persistence)

If you don’t know who the lost are - can be a common experience if in a Christian bubble
Maybe they don’t want to come back
Effort
Being persistent since it can take time
Going out of comfort zone and being generous with resources
Intentionality

19  “There was a rich man who would dress in purple and fine linen, feasting lavishly every day.  20  But a poor man named Lazarus, covered with sores, was lying at his gate.  21  He longed to be filled with what fell from the rich man’s table, but instead the dogs would come and lick his sores.  22  One day the poor man died and was carried away by the angels to Abraham’s side. The rich man also died and was buried.  23  And being in torment in Hades, he looked up and saw Abraham a long way off, with Lazarus at his side.  24  ‘Father Abraham!’ he called out, ‘Have mercy on me and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, because I am in agony in this flame!  25  “‘Son,’ Abraham said, ‘remember that during your life you received your good things, just as Lazarus received bad things, but now he is comforted here, while you are in agony.  26  Besides all this, a great chasm has been fixed between us and you, so that those who want to pass over from here to you cannot; neither can those from there cross over to us.  27  “‘Father,’ he said, ‘then I beg you to send him to my father’s house—  28  because I have five brothers—to warn them, so that they won’t also come to this place of torment.  29  “But Abraham said, ‘They have Moses and the prophets; they should listen to them.’  30  “‘No, father Abraham,’ he said. ‘But if someone from the dead goes to them, they will repent.’  31  “But he told him, ‘If they don’t listen to Moses and the prophets, they will not be persuaded if someone rises from the dead.’”

Rich man- purple, linen
Ceremonial uncleanliness- poor man was covered with sores, licked by dogs

Jews didn’t have a concept of “heaven” like we do, their vision of desired afterlife was to be reunited with their great ancestors like Abraham, Jacob, Moses, etc.
Questions:
How does the rich man use his money while he’s alive?
Buys and dresses in the nicest clothes
Buys and eats the nicest food
Generally spends all his resources on himself
What do the rich man’s actions in the afterlife reveal about how he views Lazarus? What about when both were alive?
Asks Abraham to command Lazarus to help him instead of asking Lazarus directly
Recognizes Lazarus by name, suggesting that the rich man was familiar with who he was
Generally shows how the rich man looks down on Lazarus in the afterlife, and likely did while they were both alive
Why did the rich man end up where he is after death? What needed to change for his fate to be different?
While alive, the rich man was familiar with who Lazarus was and his situation, but never bothered to help him even with the leftovers he had
The issue was not about how much or little he helped, but rather  why  the rich man didn’t help Lazarus
The rich man was only interested in doing things and spending his resources in ways that would bring benefit or satisfaction back to himself
The rich man lacked a compassionate heart, which is why he was never interested in helping Lazarus
What needed to change was the entirety of the rich man’s heart and priorities, not just his interactions with Lazarus
Why does the rich man want to warn his brothers? How does Abraham respond to his request?
Rich man realizes that it’s too late for him to be with Abraham anymore, but still hopes his brothers still have the chance
Rich man thinks that if his brothers see Lazarus resurrected that would help them reach a different fate after death
Abraham tells the rich man that even seeing someone come back from the dead wouldn’t be enough to change the fate of his brothers
The rich man believes that if his brothers act somewhat differently in life that it would lead to them having a different experience after death
Abraham explains that the issue with the rich man’s brothers is with their hearts, just like the rich man himself
What does Christian compassion look like? Why is it important?
Christian compassion looks like caring for someone  even/especially when it’s not convenient to do so
Only serving others when it’s easy or doesn’t come at a cost to ourselves isn’t really compassion, but instead convenience
Good example is parable of the Good Samaritan
True compassion is also the mark of a heart changed by the Gospel
While having compassion doesn’t earn righteousness or salvation, it’s a measuring point for how much your heart is changed by God
How have you personally seen an example of this kind of compassion in your life?

Ceremonial practice of circumcision and what it represents
Performed to officially admit a person into the OT covenant with God, and also to identify as a descendant of Abraham (Gen 17:10-11)
Also as a sign of obedience to God’s law
Law was designed to keep people away from sin and set their hearts towards God
Performed to those assumed to be previously  apart  from God
Practice of presenting first born son to God
Referenced in Numbers 18:15 as a practice to redeem the firstborn son
Performed in place of sacrificing child to God, replaced by money/animal in remembrance of God killing Egypt’s firstborn in Exodus 13
Meant to dedicate the firstborn to service for God
Socioeconomic implications of Mary/Joseph's sacrifice
From Lev:6-8, normal practice is to sacrifice a 1yr old lamb + pigeon/turtledove
Sacrificing 2 turtle doves/pigeons indicates poorer financial situation
Background on Simeon/Anna
Simeon being a faithful and devout person his entire life, so much so that he was famous for it
Historical context suggests that he was respected as an esteemed teacher
Anna’s age
Prophecy not being present since the last official prophet, at least several hundred years

section: John the Baptist Prepares the Way
text:
1  In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar—when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, Herod tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip tetrarch of Iturea and Traconitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene—  2  during the high-priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came to John son of Zechariah in the wilderness. 3  He went into all the country around the Jordan, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.  4  As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet:
“A voice of one calling in the wilderness, ‘Prepare the way for the Lord,     make straight paths for him.
5  Every valley shall be filled in,     every mountain and hill made low. The crooked roads shall become straight,     the rough ways smooth.
6  And all people will see God’s salvation.’” [ a ]
7  John said to the crowds coming out to be baptized by him, “You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath? 8  Produce fruit in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’ For I tell you that out of these stones God can raise up children for Abraham.  9  The ax is already at the root of the trees, and every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.”
10  “What should we do then?” the crowd asked.
11  John answered, “Anyone who has two shirts should share with the one who has none, and anyone who has food should do the same.”
12  Even tax collectors came to be baptized.“Teacher,” they asked, “what should we do?”
13  “Don’t collect any more than you are required to,” he told them.
14  Then some soldiers asked him, “And what should we do?”
He replied, “Don’t extort money and don’t accuse people falsely—be content with your pay.”
15  The people were waiting expectantly and were all wondering in their hearts if John might possibly be the Messiah.  16  John answered them all, “I baptize you with [ b ] water. But one who is more powerful than I will come, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you with [ c ]  the Holy Spirit and fire.  17  His winnowing fork is in his hand to clear his threshing floor and to gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.”  18  And with many other words John exhorted the people and proclaimed the good news to them.
19  But when John rebuked Herod the tetrarch because of his marriage to Herodias, his brother’s wife, and all the other evil things he had done,  20  Herod added this to them all: He locked John up in prison.
The Baptism and Genealogy of Jesus
21  When all the people were being baptized, Jesus was baptized too. And as he was praying, heaven was opened  22  and the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form like a dove. And a voice came from heaven: “You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased.”

IV Answer: The tradition in the synagogues of Jesus’ day was not to have a regular minister/preacher for each synagogue, but rather to have the Scripture read and discussed. Often a distinguished visitor was asked to read the Scripture and comment on it.

text: 6 On a Sabbath, [ b ]  while he was going through the grainfields, his disciples plucked and ate some heads of grain, rubbing them in their hands.  2  But some of the Pharisees said, “Why are you doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?”  3  And Jesus answered them, “Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him:  4  how he entered the house of God and took and ate the bread of the Presence, which is not lawful for any but the priests to eat, and also gave it to those with him?”  5  And he said to them, “The Son of Man is lord of the Sabbath.”

Read 5:33-39
What are the Pharisees accusing Jesus’ disciples of doing? What are they implying with this line of questioning?
Eating and drinking (AKA not fasting)
The Pharisees are implying that Jesus’ disciples are too happy. When fasting, the Pharisees would make a big show of how hungry & unhappy they are, in order to appear more pious through suffering.
Jesus tells the Pharisees a parable about taking new things and using it to patch up older things (garment, wineskins). How does this relate to their accusation?
Being the Son of God, Jesus is introducing the Pharisees to a new way to live in harmony with God. They are trying to take his teachings/way of life and apply it to the old laws. Since Jesus has come to fulfill the old laws and brings grace to his followers, the two are not able to be combined.
Additionally, those who have a taste of the new, will no longer desire the old

“Working” on the Sabbath (what they did can be seen as reaping, threshing, winnowing, and preparing food. Four laws violated in one action.)

section: Why do the disciples want divine punishment for the Samaritans?
text:
Normally rejection of God deserves punishment, as shown in OT
See 2 Kings 1, where God sends fire against the soldiers
Tensions in relationships between Samaritans/Jews
Seen as insulting given that the normal cultural practice of everyone leaving in the “Middle East” area was to be very hospitable to others
Why doesn’t Jesus agree with their opinion?

As Jesus will explain, the cost and burden of truly following Jesus as a disciple is very high, and it’s actually a very normal reaction to resist doing so or hold on to other things we know are familiar or comfortable instead.
Jesus chooses not to punish those who may be tempted by such a desire and say no to Him
Jesus is not currently here for judgment, but hints that judgment will come

What obstacle is in the way of each individual that approaches Jesus to follow Him? What does each interaction reveal about what true discipleship to Jesus looks like?
First individual (57-58), assumes he is simply following a rabbi similar to their time. Jesus is warning that he is much greater and does not have a place in the world. His expectation is not correct.
Is a general warning of the conditions and lifestyle a true disciple of Jesus will have - one that lacks comfort and because is focused on an end result not on Earth, will leave those practicing it feeling out of place in the world
Second individual (59-60), more focused on family matters than Jesus. The role of discipleship takes priority over family related manners.
The practice of burying relatives, especially direct family, was one held with some of the highest importance in Jewish/general culture in Jesus’ time.
Jesus’ response demonstrates that true discipleship should hold even greater importance than one’s most sacred/significant family and cultural practices
Third individual (61-62), more focused on his past. Those that look back cannot engage in discipleship. The new has replaced the old.
The purpose of discipleship is to transform us into people who are more like Jesus and therefore more like God, preparing for us life beyond Earth.
Holding too much attention to things and matters that are related to our time on Earth can be a distraction/deterrent from this process of transformation

What things jump out at you in this passage?
What’s Paul’s relationship like with the Philippians? Why is Paul so joyful?
Paul is regularly thinking about them; he sees them as partners. He thanks them for their support during his time in prison and otherwise. He yearns for them (could ask what that means). He desires for them to grow in love and for them to grow in Christ. Paul is joyful because he loves them. He has this joy that comes with partnering with this church and hearing about their growth.
What do you notice about Paul’s prayer life?
Has a vertical component of thanking God, but there is intentional praying for others, the Philippians. He isn’t just praying for them because there is a desperate need, but just regularly remembering them. What do our prayers usually look like?
Possible subtopics: content, affect, wording, frequency, posture.
Why do we pray in the first place?
Not just asking for stuff, but aligning ourselves with God. It’s part of communicating in this relationship with God. Prayer itself is acknowledging our weakness and need for God; hopefully, not just when we are in desperate need. Sometimes we pray because we feel like it’s the ‘right’ thing to do.

V19 tells us the prayers of others plus the spirit of Jesus. Paul is able to see that even his imprisonment is for greater purpose. What does v21 mean for Paul? What are the implications of this verse for us today?
This verse is Paul’s expression of his love and desire for Christ. He understands that his aim is to honor Christ as much as possible while he is on earth; he wants to labor for Jesus since Jesus is worthy. At the same time, he knows that dying means he can be with Christ forever. He actually believes in that hope and reality with no more burdens of earthly life. This verse challenges us in our attitudes today. Where is our ultimate desire? Do we want to align with what Paul is saying? If so, our priorities and outlook on life should change. Not that we drop everything and become missionaries/pastors, but we would be more conscious of what God wants to do through our work, school, relationships, etc. It also helps put our earthly experiences in perspective; we can hope in a bright future with Christ even when things don’t work out on earth according to our plan/preference.

1.  In the last section, Paul talked about Christ’s “obedience” (2:8). Paul now calls us to be obedient. Think about how Christ was obedient and think about the issues that Paul has been dealing with so far in Philippians. Summarize what Paul might have in mind when he tells us to “obey”.
Christ was obedient by humbling himself to serve others, even to the point of dying on the cross for them. Paul is calling us to live lives worthy of the gospel, to suffer gladly for the advancement of the gospel, to unite as a community for the sake of the gospel, and serve one another so that all persevere in their faith and ministry.
2.  Paul insists that they should “obey”, or “work out your salvation”, not only in Paul’s presence but much more in his absence. Why did Paul have to insist on their obedience in his absence? Why might a group of people be more prone to disobedience when their leadership is away?
If people think Paul is never coming back they may be tempted to vie for power and influence, or they may leave off faithfulness to the gospel ministry knowing that they are not being held accountable. On the other hand, the lack of Paul’s ministry, encouragement, prayers, and service to the Philippians might be felt as a big hole in the spiritual input they had been receiving.
3.  Paul says that God is at work in the Philippians. How would an understanding of this reality motivate or empower the Philippians to obey even in the absence of their leadership?
Even if Paul is not there to hold the Philippians accountable, people ought to fear that God is still among them and conduct themselves accordingly. Additionally, just because the Philippians do not have Paul ministering to them, they still have God, which is far better. People can expect God to continue working in them to bring to completion what he started with or without Paul (1:6).
4.  What is it about grumbling and questioning, that makes it impossible for a person to be “blameless and innocent”, even when they are doing “all things” they have been asked to do? Why is it so important to Paul that our attitudes match our actions?
God does not call us to outward behavior only but wants our hearts to be engaged in the manners of his kingdom. When our hearts are sour toward the things of God it comes through in our speech, even if we are “obeying” in our actions.
5.  In verse 2:14­15 Paul is reflecting on Deuteronomy 32:5. In what ways were the Israelites prevented from being “lights in the world” because of their grumbling and questioning? How might “obedient” Christians similarly be prevented from being “lights in the world” by their bad attitudes?
It would have been obvious to the nations that the Israelites often doubted God by their grumbling against him. If he was the God of the Israelites and they doubted him, how could anyone else trust him? If we grumble, we betray to the world around us that we are not willing to trust God, or that he is not enough to satisfy us, or that he is not powerful or caring enough to deal with the issues that are important to us.
